1915;article : ' metals screen trade set to evolve ' please find attached the above article from the rueters english news service
column3: 2001 . uk : interview - metals screen trade set to evolve - spectron . by andy blamey 10 / 12 / 2001 reuters english news service ( c ) reuters limited 2001 . london
column4: oct 12 ( reuters ) - electronic trading of base metals futures has established a firm foothold in the market but the nature of online trading platforms looks set to evolve further
column5: says gavin gross
column6: head of lme metals at spectron futures ltd . uk - based energy and commodities broker spectron ' s electronic platform for the trading of london metal exchange ( lme ) contracts has become required viewing for traders alongside the lme ' s own system lme select and the enron group ' s enrononline .  i think we ' ve proved that people will trade lme derivatives contracts online
column7: because there are some great advantages to doing so
column8: gross told reuters in a telephone interview .  and unlike the physical markets
column9: where things haven ' t really taken off online
column10: all three platforms are pretty much indispensable to the market .  both spectron and lme select are neutral platforms in which category 1 and category 2 lme members trade with each other
column11: while enrononline is open to a wider membership but has enron itself as the sole counterparty in each transaction . this leaves a gap in the market for a multi - party trading system open to industry participants beyond the immediate trading community
column12: gross suggested .  i think the clear trend for metals derivatives trading for the future is for open platforms which would allow dealers and clients in the market to interact with each other online
column13: he said . direct access for clients to an electronic trading environment could mean changes in the role of the broker
column14: he said .  clients will have the advantage of more control
column15: more visibility and more transparency in what they do . however
column16: they ' ll have to pay for services
column17: gross said .  you could see a situation where dealers specialise in different areas - certain dealers would provide credit functions
column18: certain institutions would provide clearing
column19: others would provide execution and certain companies would provide market - making .  difficult conditions difficult market conditions are already forcing metals traders to rethink their activities
column20: this week alone has seen n . m . rothschild & sons exit base metals trading and both bank of nova scotia and enron looking to scale back .  on the lme now you ' ve got low volumes
column21: falling volatilities
column22: falling prices and we ' re in the grips of a bear market . it ' s very
column23: very poor for business in general
column24: gross said .  there are too many dealers around chasing a shrinking amount of business . . . each company is going to have to look very carefully at their business and their staffing levels .  spectron has not been immune from declining volumes .  our volumes for the first 12 months of operation were fantastic
column25: way beyond what we had expected . however
column26: our volumes have fallen in the recent quarter
column27: gross said .  that ' s due to two factors : first
column28: the overall market activity is lower
column29: and second lme select has managed to attract some of the business that we would previously have had 100 percent of .  the company is now looking at ways to further develop its trading platform .  we ' re beginning to investigate ways to add certain features and do things differently . that might involve creating an alternative platform where clients could access prices and thereby widen the service
column31: he stressed
column32: we have to keep the interests of our dealer clients foremost .  uncertainty in the current environment
column33: the lme ' s refusal to throw its weight behind either open - outcry floor trade or its new screen system - the exchange has taken pains not to express any preference and to  allow the market to decide  - may prove to be counterproductive
column34: gross said .  by having two systems running side by side . . . the exchange is almost moving in two totally different directions
column35: he said .  there ' s a feeling that the ring is doomed
column36: which doesn ' t do anything to encourage its use
column37: while the reluctance to fully back electronic trading means that you ' re still only seeing a trickle of business going through select in terms of overall volumes .  while preferences vary in different sectors of the market
column38: the current uncertainty is helping no - one
column39: he said :  metals traders just want to trade . they just want to know with some kind of certainty how the market will be structured in future so they can structure their business to support that and make money . ;Safe Email

1920;talc98 : second call for proposals * - * - * - * - * - * - * t a l c 98 * - * - * - * - * - * - * teaching and language corpora 1998 keble college
column3: 24 - 27 july 1998 second call for proposals * note extended deadline * the use of large computer-held corpora of real language
column4: no longer novel in linguistic research
column5: is increasingly a focus of attention for language teachers . experiments in data driven learning and corpus-based methods are beginning to bear fruit in a wide range of language teaching environments . this international conference will bring together practitioners and theorists with a common interest in the usability of corpus data for such purposes as : * language teaching and learning * student-centred learning and investigation * cross-linguistic comparison * cultural and historical studies following the highly successful talc94 and talc96 conferences at lancaster university
column6: talc98 invites proposals for position papers
column7: reports of work in progress
column8: case-histories of successful corpus applications
column9: and introductions to relevant new resources . the programme will include plenary lectures from professor jean aitchison ( oxford ) and from jeremy clear ( cobuild ) . other speakers will include : guy aston ( bologna )
column10: lou burnard ( oxford )
column11: prof michael hoey ( liverpool )
column12: knut hofland ( bergen )
column13: bernhard kettemann ( graz )
column14: tony mcenery ( lancaster )
column15: chris tribble ( warsaw ) . for further details
column16: please read the conference web site at http : / / users . ox . ac . uk / ~ talc98 /
column17: or send enquiries by email to talc98 @ oucs . ox . ac . uk . timetable abstracts ( 500 - 1000 words ) should be submitted to arrive by 20 march 1998 . all proposals will be reviewed . authors of accepted papers will be notified by 10 april 1998 . the programme will be finalised during may 1998 . full papers ( up to 5000 words ) must be received by 1 june for inclusion in the conference pre-print volume . the conference will run from lunchtime on friday 24 july to lunchtime on monday july 27th
column18: with a single strand of presentations . there will be a book and software exhibit in parallel . venue and cost keble college is located in the heart of oxford
column19: one of the most beautiful university cities in europe
column20: which is easily accessible by road
column21: rail
column22: or air from most major cities . all delegates will be accomodated in modern fully-equipped study-bedrooms within a few minutes walk of the conference centre and all facilities . a single fee of approximately 350 pounds will be charged

column2: if you are a user of reference grammars and are willing to invest some seven or ten minutes
column3: you can contribute to shaping the format of an electronic framework for reference grammars we are about to develop . we are eager to have your opinion on what a good reference grammar should look like . for that purpose we have formulated a set of multiple choice questions plus some open questions
column4: divided into four major groups : quantity
column5: quality
column6: organisation
column7: ergonomy of reference grammar . if you have more than ten minutes

column5: VERBOSE=yeah. LOGABSTRACT=all) it shows up where I expect it to (the log in /root/procmail.log) At the end of this file

column11: so they want a record made. Discussion on this point is immaterial) :0 * ? test -d $ARCHIVEDIR/$DATEDIR  mkdir -p --mode=750 $ARCHIVEDIR/$DATEDIR { } :0 c $SAVEATI have several users where I forward certain spams to /dev/null . . .their procmailrc file (/home/$user/.procmailrc) looks like this: :0 * ^From: .*spermfun.com /dev/nullNow I've got a person who needs a copy of her inbound emails sent to another email address (outside the company)
column12: so I've got this recipe in her /home/$user/.procmailrc file: :0 c !user@domain.tldIt almost looks like procmail's not running a user's copy recipe after a global copy recipe

column17: if I try to log information

column19: I can redirect those other messages. column1: 1944;summary : who animal i would like to thank all those who wrote in concerning the question of whether ' who ' or ' what ' is used to ask about species of animals in various languages ( i am sorry but at the moment i cannot locate the file with the names of all those who i need to thank
column2: but i am really grateful ) . the only language so far identified which uses the equivalent of ' who ' in this situation in russian
column5: french
column6: dutch
column7: and i am pretty sure ( although my judgements are somewhat rusty here ) polish all use ' what '
column8: as does english obviously . i should add that i have seen many russian linguists ' dxescriptions of other languages in which they note that whatever the language is
column9: that it uses ' what ' rather than than ' who ' for animals . most recently
column10: i saw this in an eskimo - russain dictionary . i would be interested in hearing about any more examples of a language that uses ' who ' to ask for the species of an animal

column1: 1945;coling - acl ' 98 workshop announcements below are two more coling - acl ' 98 workshop announcements : - discourse relations and discourse markers - partially automated techniques for transcribing naturally occurring
column2: continuous speech seperated by : * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * call for papers coling - acl ' 98 workshop  discourse relations and discourse markers  august 15
column3: 1998 universiti de montrial montrial / canada ( see also : http : / / flp . cs . tu-berlin . de / ~ marker / aclcolingws . html ) the notion of discourse relation has received many different interpretations
column4: some of which are hardly compatible with one another . nonetheless
column5: there is a consensus among researchers that intersegment relations hold between adjacent portions of a text and that these relations may be signalled by linguistic means
column6: including so-called cue phrases
column7: aspect and mood shifts
column8: theme inversions
column9: and other markers . the workshop intends to bring together researchers working on discourse relations and discourse markers in different linguistic traditions and different nlp applications . the particular focus of the workshop is the issue of discourse relations from the viewpoint of linguistic realization . specifically
column10: contributions should address one or more of the following questions : o what are sound methodologies for comparing similar discourse markers ( contrastive studies
column11: distribution analyses
column12: etc . ) ? o what are sound methodologies for relating discourse relations with potential realizations ? o are there discourse relations that are always lexically signalled ? are there any that are never lexically signalled ? o what non-lexical ( i . e .
column13: syntactic or prosodic ) means are used to signal a relation ? o in production
column14: how does one decide whether to signal a relation at all ? o in production
column15: how does one motivate a choice among candidate signals for a given relation ? o in production
column16: how does the choice of signal interact with other decisions ( in particular
column17: those of linearizing some tree or graph structure ) ? o in analysis
column18: is it possible to reliably infer discourse relations from surface cues ? o in analysis
column19: how can one disambiguate polysemous signals such as  and
column20: since  ( temporal or causal ) etc . ? o what are useful lexical representations of discourse markers
column21: for both analysis and production ? o what are useful representations of discourse relations ( and the entities they relate )
column22: such that they facilitate the realization decision ? what features would one like to have handy in a representation so that choices can be made easily ? o are there significant differences between realizations in spoken and written language ? o how do individual languages differ in terms of any of the above issues ? organizing committee the workshop is organized by manfred stede ( tu berlin ) leo wanner ( university of stuttgart ) eduard hovy ( isi / usc
column23: marina del rey ) requirements for submission papers are invited that address any of the topics listed above . maximum length is 8 pages including figures and references . please use a4 or us letter format and set margins so that the text lies within a rectangle of 6 . 5 x 9 inches ( 16 . 5 x 23 cm ) . use classical fonts such as times roman or computer modern
column24: 11 to 12 points for text

column26: or as hardcopies . submissions from north america should be sent to : eduard hovy information sciences institute 4676 admiralty way marina del rey

column34: canada ) call for papers description - - - - - - - - - - the development of robust systems for speech analysis and synthesis depends crucially on the availability of well-annotated corpora of naturally occurring
column35: continuous speech . yet existing speech corpora are rarely well-annotated . a key to proper annotation is the availability of partially automated systems for linking selected portions of a visual display of speech to the corresponding transcriptions . to be of practical use
column36: such systems must be able to handle large files of digitized speech and they should permit transcriptions at different levels of analysis . this workshop will be devoted to the presentation and discussion of papers and software demonstrations which reflect the current state of the art . we invite proposals of up to 800 words which address the development

column12: john subject : im i / im ii ppa . gents attached please find a copy of the im i ppa with san antonio together with a short note from joh lamb regarding termination . i look forward to our discussion at the top of the hour . regards
column13: jfg - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - forwarded by jay godfrey / ewc / enron on 09 / 19 / 2001 12 : 17 pm - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - john lamb 09 / 19 / 2001 11 : 43 am to : jay godfrey / ewc / enron @ enron cc : subject : im i / im ii ppa . jay : the im i and im ii ppas have different
column14: but consistent
column15: approaches to the calculation of damages in the event that a party defaults under the agreement . the differences arise because the im i agreement is based on more typical ppas between a independent power generator and a utility power purchaser . on the other hand
column16: the im ii deal is a combination of such a ppa with a number of terms that more commonly foundin in power agreements between a power marketer and a buyer . consistent with most ppas with utilities
column17: the im i agreement does not specify the method for calculating actual damages that a nondefaulting party may incur in the event of a default by the other party . that methodology is left up to general contract law
column18: which is that the nondefaulting party receives actual damages in an amount that would put them in the economic position that they would have been if the defaulting party would have performed its obligations . this is basic contract law . the im ii agreement spells out in detail the damage calculation
column19: which is referred to as a  termination payment
column20: in the agreement . i understand that this approach is typical of power marketing contracts . however
column21: the mechanics are basically the same as if you went by basic contract law
column22: other than the fact that the seller is entitled to certain consequental damages as well as actual damages resulting from a breach by the buyer . in the end
column23: the nondefaulting party
column24: through the payment of the termination fee is being placed in the same economic position as if the defaulting party had performed its obligations . let me know if you want further clarification on this point . regards john;Safe Email

column2: ONLY $29.95!Setting the Home Page in KonquerorKonqueror
column4: has taken a step in the direction of IE. Like IE
column5: Konqueror is really an integrated web and file browser. You can use it equally well to view web pages and files on your system. It's been something of a hot debate whether this is actually the proper use of a browser. In fact
column6: Galeon was written specifically to answer this question - it's a web browser and a web broswer only.Regardless
column7: it can be a bit annoying to punch the Home button on the Konqueror browser and end up in your /home/user directory. Have no fear
column8: though. It's an easy change to make your actual web home page the home page in Konqueror.Open Konqueror and select Settings from the toolbar. Select Configure Konqueror
column9: and leave the default selection of File Manager as is. In the text box on the right half of the screen
column10: you'll see a tilde in the Home URL text box. That just tells Konqueror to use the user's home directory as the home URL. Changing this to a web address will set that address as your home page. Select OK to close the window.Taking it one step further
column11: click on the Home button in your Konqueror browser to open your newly-configured web home page. Then
column12: select Window and Save View Profile
column13: 'Web Browsing.' This will futher save the URL and allow your the opportunity to save the window size when the browser opens.Konqueror is more than just a web browser. But
column14: it's not so tough to make it act like a pure web browser if you just know where to look.

column1: Kernel Configuration - Part XIIDepending on who you talk to
column2: RAID can stand for Redundant Array of Independent Discs or Redundant Array of Inexpensive Discs. No matter. They both point to the same theory and practice in Linux
column3: data storage redundancy. That's today's kernel configuration section - Multi-Device Support.Let's talk first about the principles behind a RAID setup. RAID uses multiple discs for speed
column5: or data redundancy. Fundamentally
column6: there are 5 levels of RAID in Linux
column7: Linear
column8: RAID-0
column9: RAID-1
column10: RAID-4
column11: and RAID-5.Linear RAID uses two or more discs
column12: appending data from one to another. In other words
column13: when disc 1 is full
column14: disc 2 steps in to store data. There is no redundancy in Linear RAID - only an increase in storage capacity. Further
column15: there's no marked increase in data access speed because you're accessing one drive in the RAID array at a time.RAID-0 stripes data across the RAID drives. Some data will be written to the first drive
column16: some to the second
column17: etc. Like Linear RAID
column18: RAID-0 provides no redundancy. Because the data has been written in parallel across the drives
column19: not all data exists on all drives. Lose a drive and your data is gone. RAID-0 will
column20: however
column21: decrease data access time. Your system will run more quickly.RAID-1
column22: unlike Linear and RAID-0
column23: does provide data redundancy. This is the first level in which data is mirrored across the drives in the RAID array. All data that exists on one drive exists on all the others. RAID-1 requires at least two drives and they should be of equal size
column24: otherwise
column25: your overall RAID array will be the size of the smallest drive. Performance with RAID-1 can actually be slower than with a single drive or RAID-0
column26: as all the data is written across multiple discs.RAID-4 is
column27: for the most part
column28: pretty useless. It reserves one disc for parity information while striping the data across the others. This is much like Linear mode
column29: with an additional disc thrown in for parity data. Parity data can be used to reconstruct and retrieve the data on the other drives
column30: but this really isn't a redundant method of data storage. Consequently
column31: RAID-4 is probably the least used of the RAID schemes.RAID-5 is designed for 3 or more discs and provides both redundancy and speed. Like RAID-4
column32: RAID-5 pays close attention to parity data. However
column33: rather than reserving a device in the RAID array for this data
column34: it's written across the array. Because the parity data is written across the array
column35: data recovery can be accomplished fairly quickly. In fact
column36: using a spare disc configuration will allow RAID-5 to reconstruct the data to the spare disc immediately after the failure of a drive. Because of it's increased speed and redundancy
column37: RAID-5 is probably the most common setup for multiple storage devices.With all that in mind
column38: you'll need to make a choice in your kernel configuration. Do you have mutliple drives of the same size that you'd like to configure as a RAID array? The Multi-Device Support section of the kernel configuration will allow you to do this. In fact
column39: you'll be able to set the RAID level
column40: as well. Again
column41: evaluate your needs and select the appropriate option.Tomorrow
column42: it's on to networking options in your kernel configuration.

2018;re : 5 . 1225 linguistics and imperialism with regard to hoberman 's comment . it would not make sense to say that linguistics is inherently imperialistic in nature
column2: any more than it would for any other science
column3: since linguistics is multi-faceted and has many purposes
column4: some now well established and others continually evolving
column5: e . g .
column6: forensic  applications of linguistics etc . since language is universal
column7: applications for linguistics are universal . in my earlier comments i dwelt on diversity among languages because that 's where the connection between linguistics ( mainly as an aid to learning and teaching languages ) and multilingual empires ( =  imperialism  ) is easiest to see . however
column8: i also noted that there are people who are interested in language and linguistic diversity for its own sake . i suspect that this is universal . although it may be reflected differently in different cultures . maybe the universality of interest in language and linguistic diversity is reflected in myths about the origin of such diversity
column9: or other kinds of  pre-linguistic  explanations . among cultures which seem particularly ethnocentric to me
column10: classic athenian culture perhaps was less encouraging to interest in other languages than most cultures ( with the us perhaps close behind but also with a complex fear and insecurity about languages other than english ) . nevertheless
column11: we see from plato 's cratylus that differences between greek ( in its various diachronic forms ) and the  barbarian  languages was put to philosophical use . if you read cratylus
column12: you ' ll see that plato
column13: through socrates
column14: was putting some value on philosophical arguments which brought in data from other languages . ( even though there 's a lot of sarcasm and tongue in cheek in the whole issue as plato treats it in cratylus
column15: i . e .
column16: whether the words of language are  natural  or  conventional  / are there  correct  words for ideas / concepts / things ? - - plato is always a polemicist
column17: reacting to rival schools of thought . ) i would like to re-open the issue ( i think it was once opened before on the list ) about how different cultures  explain  language diversity
column18: and whether there is a culture which prevents all individual members from being interested in language for its own sake . i do n't think that could logically be possible - - but what do i know ? in any case
column19: this might give us some insights into the  prehistory of linguistics
column20: and also into the still present motivations of some linguists to attach themselves to this aspect of our culture . benji;Safe Email

column1: 2055;that helps. There's still so little info on TES and those of us here since RazorV1 know how it works. I did set my min_cf to ac-100 which I thought would be zero. So the way you are suggesting that it works now is that everyone has a trust level of 1 and have to work their way up. Your trust level increases when someone nominates the same message as spam. This must have been the new changes made at the beginning of the week unless the changes dumped everyone's trust level. Now here come the questions...What engine signature does TES look at? Does it have to be the same e1 signature or does it use the e2 or e4 signatures. How many people have to nominate the message before everyones rating increases? How many revokes decreases someones rating? Does a single revoke decrease the rating of everyone that nominated the message? If a newby reports a message that has already been reported does their trust level immediately go up? In the case of revoking
column2: does someone with a trust level of 1 have the capability to revoke a message submitted by multiple people with higher trust levels? -----Original Message----- From: Vipul Ved Prakash [mailto:mail@vipul.net] Sent: Thursday
column4: 2002 4:22 AM To: razor-users@example.sourceforge.net Subject: Re: [Razor-users] What's wrong with the Razor servers now? Bobby
column5: Couple of things: If you are not a trusted reporter
column6: your reports will not have an immediate effect. It takes a bunch of trusted reporters to bump up the confidence of a signature to a point where it is considered to be spam. This might be frustrating initially
column7: but as the number of trusted users grows the time delay between nominations and determination will become shorter. Of course
column8: it's a lot more frustating for people to have their legit mail filtered out due to incorrect reporting.Also
column9: for the purpose of testing
column10: I'd suggest making your min_cf (in razor-agents.conf) to 0. min_cf defaults to the server recommended average confidence
column11: which at the moment is 1. Setting min_cf to 0 should return true for whatever you submit (as long as it was not revoked by a trusted user).apt/fire sync with honor every 5 minutes
column12: so you'd have to wait for a _maximum_ of 5 minutes before signatures propagate.cheers

column1: 2063;universal grammar the following is a book which readers of this list might find of interest . for more information please visit http : / / mitpress . mit . edu / promotions / books / craihs98 investigations in universal grammar a guide to experiments on the acquisition of syntax and semantics stephen crain and rosalind thornton this introductory guide to language acquisition research is presented within the framework of universal grammar
column2: a theory of the human faculty for language . the authors focus on two experimental techniques for assessing children 's linguistic competence : the elicited production task
column4: and the truth value judgment task
column5: a comprehension task . their methodologies are designed to overcome the numerous obstacles to empirical investigation of children 's language competence . they produce research results that are more reproducible and less likely to be dismissed as an artifact of improper experimental procedure . in the first section of the book
column6: the authors examine the fundamental assumptions that guide research in this area
column7: they present both a theory of linguistic competence and a model of language processing . in the following two sections

column2: 25-27 sept 98 endangered languages - what role for the the specialist ? - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - edinburgh
column3: scotland - 25-27 september 1998 call for papers the workshop will provide a forum for researchers and activists working for the maintenance of indigenous languages that face an uncertain future . conference scope and aims in recent years
column4: number of support organizations have established themselves
column5: all aiming to mobilize research effort
column6: popular opinion and money in defence of declining languages . the question is often raised of how these outsiders can really help the cause that they have identified . language communities must have inner strength in order to survive
column7: or at least the will and the means to go on using their traditional tongues . outside organizations
column8: however well-meaning
column9: cannot supply such qualities directly . some ask whether the organizations even have the right to try to interfere . this conference
column10: the second organized by the foundation for endangered languages
column11: is seeking answers to one part of this question . how can language specialists
column12: whether professional linguists
column13: educators
column14: media professionals or whoever
column15: actually contribute to language maintenance ? we shall be looking for testimony on the actual effects of professional involvement on small language communities throughout the world : both community members
column16: and the professionals themselves will have their tales to tell . we do not expect a common set of conclusions to emerge from this sharing of experience and analysis . but we shall be looking at the variety we find
column17: and asking if it points to a good way to define the roles of the support organizations : how they can complement one another
column18: perhaps sharing techniques
column19: perhaps transmitting knowledge ? some themes that need to be addressed : when does the professional best act as an external consultant
column20: when as a team-player ? what are useful relations : among grammarians
column21: lexicographers and sociolinguists ? among community-leaders
column22: language-activists and language-scientists ? among ordinary speakers
column23: creative users
column24: broadcasters and publishers ? what have been great successes in specialist language work
column25: and what motivated the people responsible ? how does local work benefit from el support organizations with a global or continental view ? is the need for technical assistance
column26: production of materials
column27: publicity
column28: funding
column29: political agitation ? should el support organizations themselves specialize ? if so how : regionally
column30: or by function ? the dates will be 25-27 september 1998
column31: and the venue the pollock halls in edinburgh . there will be a preliminary volume of proceedings distributed at the conference . presentations will last twenty minutes each
column32: with a further ten minutes for discussion . all presentations should be accessible largely in english
column33: but use of the languages of interest

column1: 2082;acl workshop on translingual information management acl / coling-98 workshop on translingual information management current levels and future abilities august 16
column2: 1998 ( following acl / coling-98 ) university of montreal
column4: canada ) call for papers description - - - - - - - - - - the development of natural language applications which handle multi-lingual and multi-modal information is the next major challenge facing the field of computational linguistics . over the past 50 years
column5: a variety of language-related capabilities has been developed in areas such as machine translation
column6: information retrieval
column7: and speech recognition
column8: together with core capabilities such as information extraction
column9: summarization
column10: parsing
column11: generation
column12: multimedia planning and integration
column13: statistics-based methods
column14: ontologies
column15: lexicon construction and lexical representations
column16: and grammar . the next few years will require the extension of these technologies to encompass multi-lingual and multi-modal information . extending current technologies will require integration of the various capabilities into multi-functional natural language systems . however
column17: there is today no clear vision of how these technologies could or should be assembled into a coherent framework . what would be involved in connecting a speech recognition system to an information retrieval engine
column18: and then using machine translation and summarization software to process the retrieved text ? how can traditional parsing and generation be enhanced with statistical techniques ? what would be the effect of carefully crafted lexicons on traditional information retrieval ? this workshop is a follow-on to an nsf - sponsored workshop held in conjunction with the first international conference on language resources and evaluation in granada
column19: spain ( may 1998 )
column20: at which an international panel of invited experts will consider these questions in an attempt to identify the most effective future directions of computational linguistics research - - especially in the context of the need to handle multi-lingual and multi-modal information . the follow-on acl workshop is intended to open the discussion to the computational inguistics community as a whole . the workshop will include ample time for discussion . a report summarizing the discussions at granada will be available before the acl workshop . topics - - - - - the workshop will focus on the following fundamental questions : 1 . what is the current level of capability in each of the major areas of the field dealing with language and related media of human communication ? 2 . how can ( some of ) these functions be integrated in the near future
column21: and what kind of systems will result ? 3 . what are the major considerations for extending these functions to handle multi-lingual and multi-modal information
column22: particularly in integrated systems of the type envisioned in ( 2 ) ? in particular
column23: we will consider these questions in relation to the following areas : o multi-lingual resources ( lexicons
column24: ontologies
column25: corpora
column26: etc . ) o information retrieval

column70: we have a problem : how much is enron worth ? by christina cheddar of dow jones newswires 10 / 31 / 2001 dow jones news service ( copyright ( c ) 2001
column71: dow jones & company
column72: inc . ) new york - ( dow jones ) - with billions of dollars shaved off of the market capitalization of enron corp . ( ene ) in the past two weeks
column73: the stock is trading at about its book value
column74: begging the question : so how much is it worth anyway ? the answer is far from easy . ever since enron metamorphosed from a stodgy gas pipeline company into what was seen by many as a dynamic energy trading firm
column75: the company has become increasingly more difficult to understand . just a glance at the wide - range of wall street analysts who follow the company illustrates the point . in the mix are analysts who track natural gas and the pipeline industry as well as those who follow electric utilities . one enticing prospect is that the assets in its portfolio are valuable in and of themselves and could be seen by some as worthwhile acquisition targets . by enron ' s own definition
column76: the company houses four main divisions : enron wholesale services
column78: enron transportation services
column79: and enron broadband services . wholesale services houses the company ' s energy marketing business and enrononline . this segment accounts for the bulk of enron ' s profits
column80: and has become synonymous with what enron means to most people today . not only does enron trade gas
column82: but it also trades commodities such as pulp and paper
column84: lumber
column85: plastics and even weather risk . enron energy services is the company ' s retail arm . the company provides electricity

column1: 2100;workshop announcement for distribution * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * call for papers call for papers call for papers * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * acl / coling-98 workshop on partially automated techniques for transcribing naturally occurring
column3: 1998 ( following acl / coling-98 ) university of montreal
column5: canada ) call for papers description - - - - - - - - - - the development of robust systems for speech analysis and synthesis depends crucially on the availability of well-annotated corpora of naturally occurring
column6: continuous speech . yet existing speech corpora are rarely well-annotated . a key to proper annotation is the availability of partially automated systems for linking selected portions of a visual display of speech to the corresponding transcriptions . to be of practical use
column7: such systems must be able to handle large files of digitized speech and they should permit transcriptions at different levels of analysis . this workshop will be devoted to the presentation and discussion of papers and software demonstrations which reflect the current state of the art . we invite proposals of up to 800 words which address the development
column8: use
column9: evaluation

column1: 2116;13th paclic the 13th pacific asia conference on language
column5: taiwan
column6: r . o . c . second call for papers the department of computer science and information engineering
column7: national cheng kung university
column8: is pleased to announce that the 13th pacific asia conference on language
column9: information and computation ( paclic 13 ) will be held in the grand hotel
column10: taipei
column11: taiwan
column12: r . o . c .
column13: on february 10-12
column14: 1999 . scope : the conference is an annual meeting of scholars with a wide range of interest in theoretical and computational linguistics . papers are invited on substantial
column15: original
column16: and unpublished research on all aspects of theoretical and computational linguistics
column17: including

column1: 2117;logic linguistics and information first announcement and call for papers esslli-99 workshop on focus and presupposition in multi-speaker discourse university of utrecht
column2: 9-13 august 1999 context : the workshop is part of the 11th european summer school  logic linguistics and information  ( esslli )
column3: to be held in utrecht from 9-20 august 1999 . the esslli summer school is organized under the auspices of the european association for logic
column4: language and information ( folli ) . previous esslli summer schools have been highly successful
column5: attracting around 500 students from europe and elsewhere . the school has developed into an important meeting place and forum for discussion for students and researchers interested in the interdisciplinary study of logic
column6: language and information . for more information on esslli ' 99 see : http : / / esslli . let . uu . nl / . workshop description : the aim of the workshop is to explore the interrelation between theories of focus
column7: theories of presupposition and their implementation in a formal theory of dialogue . topics to be discussed include : - the relation between focus and presupposition . - the role of answer focus in formal models of questions-answer exchanges . - the treatment of presupposition in multi-speaker discourse . - the relation between deaccentuation
column8: contextual givenness
column9: and presupposition . - the role of focus and deaccenting in establishing discourse coherence . practical matters : paper presentations will be 45 minutes long ( including 15 minutes for discussion ) . abstracts should not exceed 1500 words
column10: and can be submitted either by email or by regular mail . email submissions should be in postscript or plain ascii . please include  esslli workshop  in the subject line of your message
column11: and send it to : bart . geurts @ mpi . nl abstract submissions by regular mail should consist of 3 copies
column12: and be addressed to : bart geurts max planck institute for psycholinguistics postbox 310 nl-6500 ah nijmegen the netherlands workshop speakers are required to register for the summer school . however
column13: workshop speakers will be able to register at a reduced rate to be determined by the organizing committee . dates : - deadline for submissions of abstracts : 1 march 1999 - notification of acceptance : 1 may 1999 - workshop to be held : august 9-13 for any questions
column14: please contact the organizers : bart geurts university of osnabrueck & max planck institute for psycholinguistics
column15: nijmegen bart . geurts @ mpi . nl manfred krifka university of texas at austin krifka @ mail . utexas . edu rob van der sandt university of nijmegen rvdsandt @ phil . kun . nl;Safe Email

column1: Date: Not suppliedJakob Nielsen on Offshore Usability[1]: To save costs
outsourcing Web projects to countries with cheap labor. Unfortunately
countries lack strong usability traditions and their developers have limited
access -- if any -- to good usability data from the target users. Offshore usability is a specific case of the general offshore design problem.

column2: software teams are not successful when

column1: design or management are done in a different physical location than
programming. Once I actually had a job where I was in New York
any management input I had literally no choice but to go to the CEO because at
least he was awake during the same hours as I was. You can't get things done
like this. A good project team relies on hundreds of small interactions a day.
Here in the Fog Creek offices
column2: we have 10 small conversations about FogBUGZ 3.0

column1: development every day. What I don't understand is people who think it's OK to move the developers ten
time zones away from their managers and expect good results. Those same people
would scream bloody murder if you told them that you were going to
send the whole _management_ team to Bangalore or Beijing.[1] http://www.useit.com/alertbox/20020916.html

column1: 2122;organizational announcement it is with regret that i have to announce that jeff skilling is leaving enron . today
column2: the board of directors accepted his resignation as president and ceo of enron . jeff is resigning for personal reasons and his decision is voluntary . i regret his decision
column3: but i accept and understand it . i have worked closely with jeff for more than 15 years
column5: and have had few
column6: if any
column7: professional relationships that i value more . i am pleased to say that he has agreed to enter into a consulting arrangement with the company to advise me and the board of directors . now it ' s time to look forward . with jeff leaving
column8: the board has asked me to resume the responsibilities of president and ceo in addition to my role as chairman of the board . i have agreed . i want to assure you that i have never felt better about the prospects for the company . all of you know that our stock price has suffered substantially over the last few months . one of my top priorities will be to restore a significant amount of the stock value we have lost as soon as possible . our performance has never been stronger
column9: our business model has never been more robust
column10: our growth has never been more certain
column11: and most importantly
column12: we have never had a better nor deeper pool of talent throughout the company . we have the finest organization in american business today . together
column13: we will make enron the world ' s leading company . on thursday at 10 : 00 a . m . houston time
column14: we will hold an all employee meeting at the hyatt . we will broadcast the meeting to our employees around the world where technically available
column15: and i look forward to seeing many of you there .;Safe Email

column1: 2175;chinese dialectology yuen ren society for the promotion of chinese dialect fieldwork annual conference saturday
column2: 6 march 1999 submissions are now being accepted for a conference to be held on saturday
column4: at rutgers university in new jersey . the society welcomes presentations of a non-formalist character on any aspect of hann chinese dialectology
column5: including original field reports
column6: comparative-historical studies
column7: linguistic geography and contact
column8: sociolinguistics
column9: and taxonomy . presentations on any aspect of chinese dialects or their social context are welcome
column10: but please note that the society favors presentations that include abundant evidence
column11: in the form of either dialect data or other explicit documentation as appropriate . papers may be delivered in english or mandarin chinese . to submit a paper
column12: please send a detailed abstract to one of the addresses below . deadline for submitting abstracts is : 31 december
column13: 1998 . we expect to accept only ten papers in all . the yuen ren society is devoted to the practice of descriptive dialect fieldwork
column14: and especially welcomes reports on little-known dialects . david prager branner r . vanness simmons c / o yuen ren society c / o east asian languages & cultures 440 riverside drive
column15: # 73 330 scott hall new york
column16: ny 10027-6831 usa rutgers university new brunswick
column17: nj 08901-1164 usa fax : ( 212 ) 865-5507 fax : ( 732 ) 932-7926 email : < yuen . ren . society @ bigfoot . com > < rsimmon @ rci . rutgers . edu > or < charmii @ bigfoot . com >;Safe Email

2186;sum : size adjs and quantifiers about a month ago
column2: i posted the following query : i ' m looking for examples
column4: of quantifiers that are formally related to size adjectives . so far
column5: i am familiar with the following three examples : english : little > a little lao : nohy5 > nohy5 neu : ng2 little little one  little   a little  minangkabau : ketek > saketek little one-little  little   a little  is anybody familiar with more such examples ? in spite of the typological and geographical diversity of these three languages
column6: the above constructions are strikingly similar . this raises the following further questions : ( 1 ) are there any analogous examples where  many  is derived from  big  ? ( 2 ) are there any examples where the derivation is in the other direction
column7: ie . where a size adjective
column8: eg .  little  is derived from a quantifier
column9: eg .  a few  ? * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * the above query triggered numerous interesting responses
column10: for which i am grateful to the following residents of the global virtual village : robert beard
column11: steven berbeco
column12: jonathan david bobaljik
column13: john cowan
column14: jane edwards
column15: f . gladney
column16: arthur holmer
column17: knut lambrecht
column18: pierre larrivee
column19: ann lindvall
column20: edith moravcsik
column21: geoffrey s . nathan
column22: chris pountain
column23: ines shaw
column24: nancy stenson
column25: frits stuurman
column26: cynthia vakareliyska
column27: 0ystein alexander vangsnes
column28: peansiri vongvipanond
column29: and a person who wished to remain anonymous . in a nutshell
column30: all of the responses but one provided data from european languages . i do not know enough to say whether this areal patterning is of the phenomenon in question
column31: or rather of the respondents to the query
column32: and the languages that they are familiar with . however
column33: the data suggested that formal relationships between quantifiers and size adjectives are indeed widespread
column34: and provided an affirmative answer to the first specific query
column35: with examples of the derivation of  many  from  big  . in what follows
column36: i provide a selection of typical responses ( if anybody wants the responses in their entirety
column37: they can contact me directly ) . some more examples of  little  >  a little  : swedish : liten > lite  little   a little  irish : beag > beaga ' n  little   a little  french : petit > un petit  little   a little  russian : mal / malo / mala > malo  little   a little  ( short predicate forms ) polish : maly > malo  little   a little  bulgarian : maluk / malko / malka > malko  little   a little  some respondents offered interesting diachronic comments :  [ t ] he latin adjectives for ' little '
column38: parvus and paulus
column39: were replaced by what is often seen as an ' onomatopoeic ' creation ( * pittinnus for spanish ) . the adverb parum
column40: which is morphologically related to parvus is replaced by a form * paucu
column41: which existed in classical latin only in the plural ( pauci ) with the meaning ' ( a ) few ' . in the medieval romance languages
column42: old spanish _ poco _
column43: old catalan _ poc _ and old occitan _ pauc _ are however attested in the meaning of ' little ' .  [ chris pountain ]  [ t ] he latin root is from ie * pou / pau
column44: which gives english few
column45: foal
column46: as well as latin ( and english ) pauper
column47: poverty
column48: not to mention greek paed ` child ' ( paediatrician etc . ) so all the ` small ' and ` few ' meanings are intermingled throughout all the ie etyma .  [ geoffrey s . nathan ] and now
column49: in response to question ( 1 )
column50: some examples of  big  >  many  : quebec french : gros > gros gros  big   a lot  irish : mo ' r > mo ' ra ' n  big   a lot  ( negative polarity ) polish : duzy > duzo  big   a lot  and a general diachronic comment :  slavic _ comparative _ quantifier  more  has the same root ( bol - ) as adj  big  ( old church slavonic bolii
column51: modern russian bol 's hoj ) .  many / much  is mnogo / mnogi in the slavic languages
column52: root * minog - ( short i ) - - there 's no etymologically related adj meaning  big  . ( the root in the comparative shows up as * bolj - in the comparative quantifier and adjs
column53: but i am assuming the j is a suffix [ . . . ] . i think russian is the only modern language where this root still shows up in the adj .  big
column54: though all of them except modern bulgarian ( and probably macedonian ) still have the comparative quantifier in bol . vasmer 's etymological dictionary of the russian language relates the root to sanskrit baliyan ( acute accent on first a
column55: long mark over i and second a )
column57: balisthas ( acute over first a
column58: dot under first s and t )
column59: strongest
column60: balam  ( acute over first a )  strength  . russian has two different comparative forms with this root in addition to the adj  big  ( bol 's hoj ) : comparative quantifier bol 's he ( as in  more money  ) and adverb bolee ( as in  more interesting  ) .  [ cynthia vakareliyska ] as for question ( 2 )
column61: pertaining to derivations in the opposite direction ( from quantifier to size adjective )
column62: here the evidence is still less clear . one respondent [ ann lindvall ] suggested some possible examples from swedish and greek . in fact
column63: in the above slavic examples
column64: the directionality is not immediately clear
column65: and may perhaps be most appropriately characterized as a nondirectional identity of ( neuter-form ) adjective and quantifier . however
column66: i still have n't encountered any uncontroversial examples of size adjectives that are derived from quantifiers . finally
column67: two interesting comments on related phenomena :  hungarian : ' a little ' or 's omewhat ' ( such as in  she is a little late .  or  a somewhat over-ripe pear was lying on the table .  ) : _ kicsit _
column68: which consists of _ kicsi _ ( predicative form of the the adjective for 's mall ' ) plus _ t _
column70: ' extremely ' ( such as in the above sentences
column71: with  little  /  somewhat  replaced with  very  /  extremely  ) : _ nagyon _
column72: which consists of _ nagy _ ' big ' and _ on _
column73: a de - adjectival adverbializer . these are ad-verbal and ad-adjectival quantifiers . adnominal quantifiers such as ' many ' and ' few ' do not have to do with size adjectives .  [ edith moravcsik ]  i suspect that the thai and lao adverb ( ? ) nak  great deal
column74: a lot  and the adjective nak  heavy  are derivatives of one another ( strange ? ) through grammaticalization . this verbal quantifier is more prevalent in lao
column75: lanna thai dialect and isan dialect ( all geographically and historically related ) than in bangkok thai .  [ peansiri vongvipanond ];Safe Email

2192;enron global messaging announcement over the last few months
column2: we have been discussing our standard e - mail platform with you
column3: our customer . your feedback from the various demonstrations
column4: surveys and technology showcases validated that e - mail is a vital part of your ability to communicate effectively . however
column5: your feedback also indicated that you need your e - mail client to have additional functionality and increased integration with other applications you use . therefore
column6: to meet the demands of our fast - paced business
column7: enron net works is standardizing our e - mail platform by deploying microsoft outlook 2000 to all the business units we currently support for messaging . ( project plans for ebs
column8: ees and azurix are still being finalized and will be communicated separately . ) this conversion from lotus notes to outlook 2000 will improve your ability to communicate and provide a more consistent look and feel across the standard office applications you use on a daily basis . we are excited about this opportunity to provide a more robust
column9: full function solution for your messaging needs . to provide you with additional details about the conversion from lotus notes to outlook 2000
column10: we are including a list of frequently asked questions about this project . how does this project affect me ? your current lotus notes e - mail system will be converted to microsoft outlook 2000 . what is microsoft outlook 2000 ? outlook 2000 is the messaging client you will use to read your e - mail
column11: update your calendar and personal address book
column12: record to do lists
column13: etc . why are we switching to outlook 2000 ? outlook 2000 integrates more effectively with our new operating system
column14: windows 2000
column15: and the microsoft products that enron currently uses . with outlook 2000
column16: we can provide you with a more robust mail platform including the following new features : instant messaging  ) ability to send person - to - person
column17: immediate
column18: pop - up messages . improved palm / ce synchronization  ) allows for simpler and quicker updates of your hand held device from multiple places . conferencing server  ) ability to conduct video conferences from your desktop . web access  ) ability to retrieve your enron e - mail via a browser . fax integration  ) ability to send / receive faxes from your e - mail inbox . voice mail integration  ) ability to have your voice mail delivered to your e - mail inbox for retrieval . when will the outlook 2000 rollout start and when will i get it ? the pilot will begin in late october with the production rollout beginning in late november . we are finalizing our business unit rollout schedule . additional information will be provided to all business units as it becomes available . project updates will be posted on the project section of the it central web site at http : / / itcentral . enron . com . additionally

column5: an optimal artificial language should be designed so that its messages survive unscathed through the worst static . ergo
column6: we want * maximal phonetic differentiation * ( tm ) of the vowels
column7: we pick those maximally distant : a
column8: i
column9: u . of the consonants
column10: ditto : a dental
column11: a labial
column12: a velar . having picked the most differentiated points of articulation we must also pick the most deifferentiated manners thereof . fricative
column13: nasal
column14: stop should do nicely . and let us use voicing to help along . that leaves us with * three maximally distant consonants *
column15: which are : m
column16: z
column17: k . so far
column18: so good . but we can do better still . let each consonant be associated with one
column19: and only one
column20: vowel
column21: so that
column22: if either consonant or vowel manages to get mangled in the transmission
column23: you can restitute one from the other . naturally
column24: we would match vowels and consonants to ensure least articulatory effort
column25: lest speakers
column26: tired by too much tongue and lip shifting
column27: start slurring their words . there are n't two ways about it : i goes with z
column28: u with m
column29: a with k . so there we have it
column30: the perfect language for noise-free communication . it 's cv
column31: no consonant clusters
column32: no diphthongs
column33: and each syllable starts with exactly one consonant and has only one vowel . if the consonant is z the vowel is i
column34: and so on ( how lazy can one get ! the list of possibilities is short indeed
column35: yet i wrote  and so on  ) . ergo
column36: it has only three possible syllables : zi
column37: ka
column38: mu
column39: thereby being some 130 times easier than chinese ( with its 400 + possible syllables ) . and consider this sample vocabulary ( i leave the meanings to your imagination ) : zizi kaka mumu zizimu kakamu infants will learn it easily ! consider all its advantages : your children will speak fluently before they are two ! one of the first
